user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UT_ConfigureGenericStubReturnValue:
```c
void UT_ConfigureGenericStubReturnValue(UT_EntryKey_t FuncKey, const void *ValuePtr, size_t ValueSize,
                                        UT_ValueGenre_t ValueGenre, int32 Counter, const char *TypeName)
{
    UT_StubTableEntry_t *StubPtr;
    UT_EntryType_t       ReqEntryType;

    StubPtr = UT_GetStubEntry(FuncKey, UT_ENTRYTYPE_UNUSED);

    /*
     * For deferred retval configs, this always adds a new entry.  But
     * for constant retval configs, it should replace the existing entry if
     * there is one.
     */
    if (Counter > 0)
    {
        ReqEntryType = UT_ENTRYTYPE_RETVAL_CONFIG_DEFERRED;
        StubPtr      = NULL;
    }
    else
    {
        ReqEntryType = UT_ENTRYTYPE_RETVAL_CONFIG_CONSTANT;
        StubPtr      = UT_GetStubEntry(FuncKey, ReqEntryType);
    }

    if (StubPtr == NULL)
    {
        StubPtr = UT_GetStubEntry(FuncKey, UT_ENTRYTYPE_UNUSED);
    }

    if (StubPtr == NULL)
    {
        UtAssert_Abort("Cannot configure return value - UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS too low?");
    }
    else
    {
        StubPtr->FuncKey = FuncKey;

        StubPtr->EntryType         = ReqEntryType;
        StubPtr->Data.Rvc.Genre    = ValueGenre;
        StubPtr->Data.Rvc.Counter  = Counter;
        StubPtr->Data.Rvc.ActualSz = ValueSize;
        StubPtr->Data.Rvc.TypeName = TypeName;

        if (ValueGenre == UT_ValueGenre_OPAQUE)
        {
            /* For "unknown" types the pointer is stored directly - this allows for ANY return type of ANY size,
             * but requires that the caller maintain the buffer in scope until the test completes */
            StubPtr->Data.Rvc.Buf.IndirectPtr = ValuePtr;
        }
        else
        {
            /* For any of the recognized typical return types, a copy is made and stored in the state buffer */
            UT_StoreRetval(&StubPtr->Data.Rvc.Buf, ValuePtr, ValueSize, ValueGenre);
        }
    }
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Other code fragments do not need investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13: the function parameters ValuePtr and TypeName are already declared with const qualification (const void *ValuePtr, const char *TypeName), so their declarations comply with the rule. Most other assignments and operations in the function involve non-pointer types (integers, enums, sizes, structure fields that are not pointers) and therefore are not relevant to pointer const-qualification. The only places where the const-qualified pointers might be assigned to or passed to entities that could drop the const qualifier are the three fragments listed above (direct assignment to IndirectPtr, assignment to TypeName field, and the call to UT_StoreRetval which may accept a non-const pointer). Those should be inspected to confirm the target fields/parameters are declared with appropriate const qualifiers; all other lines do not present a potential const-qualification violation and so need not be investigated.
